some limited success with Hubris on Mac after building GHC head and applying steven's patch to cabal - 21/28 tests are passing. Excelsior!
@jamesbritt do you have any blocker bugs on Ubuntu, btw? i still want to get rid of the newgem and c2hs dependencies.
@jamesbritt i'm quixotic like that :) i'd like there to be a path that works on Mac, even if it's rocky.
@jamesbritt ghc won't output x86_64 code on Mac yet, so you need a ruby built on i386 if you want Hubris to work.
indulging in the baseless optimism of the unrepentant programmer. this time for sure.
@jamesbritt workaround - set EXTLDFLAGS = -arch i386 in Ruby's Makefile. can't do it from ./configure, though.
@jamesbritt what does 'file `which ruby`' give you? mine says x86_64, but ruby --version gives i386-darwin-10.0.0
anyone had any luck compiling ruby for i386 on a 64 bit mac? looking at you, @jamesbritt...

@brettdargan I'm more annoyed about the general perception that if you drop down to SQL you're somehow cheating, or a dirty lazy programmer.
@brettdargan that's a good point. ORMs are handy for dealing with small portions of a data set, but they're miserable for reporting.
swears never to buy cheap screwdrivers again. I don't use Windows, why do I put up with shitty tools in the real world?
@woollyams I've used Arel - it's better than AR, just because it's just another relational algebra syntax like SQL. Same abstraction level.
@rufuspost again I'm mostly frustrated with myself - spent way too long trying to make an ORM query performant. SQL took 10 minutes.
If Ruby devs love DSLs so much, why is there so little love for SQL? ORMs are a hacky impedance mismatch at best.
